questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past 7-days. The patient recently returned from a 2-week trip to the Dominican Republic. She was prescribed antimalarial chemoprophylaxis but forgot to take it. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and “chronic joint pain”. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Laboratory evaluation shows mild anemia and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral blood smear findings are shown below. After a complete evaluation, the patient is started on hydroxychloroquine. Which of the following findings can also be managed with the medication?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid
Proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joint stiffness
Intensely pruritic papules and pustules on the extensor surface of extremities
Well-defined erythematous plaque with silvery scales
Fluctuating and fatigable proximal muscle weakness

questions.solution:
This patient presents with high fevers, chills, anemia, and splenomegaly after visiting the Dominican Republic (where malaria is endemic). Peripheral blood smear reveals banana-shaped organisms. These findings are concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection, and the patient is started on hydroxychloroquine.

Other therapeutic indications of hydroxychloroquine include:
 
  •  Treatment of chronic discoid erythematosus and systemic lupus erythematosus in adults 
  •  Treatment of acute and chronic rheumatoid arthritis in adults 
  •  Dominant skin, nasal mucosal, and sinus sarcoidosis
  •  Antiphospholipid syndrome 

Option Analysis

❌ Negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid:
Incorrect: Gouty arthritis presents negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid. Treatment options include glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and colchicine. Hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the management of gouty arthritis.  
✅ Proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joint stiffness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intensely pruritic papules and pustules on the extensor surface of extremities:
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with intensely pruritic papules and pustules on the extensor surface of the extremities. The condition is associated with underlying celiac disease and is managed with a gluten-free diet and dapsone. Hydroxychloroquine is ineffective in managing dermatitis herpetiformis.  
❌ Well-defined erythematous plaque with silvery scales:
Incorrect: Psoriasis presents with well-defined erythematous plaques with silvery scales. Common treatment options include emollients, corticosteroids, and topical vitamin D analogs. Hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the management of psoriasis.  
❌ Fluctuating and fatigable proximal muscle weakness:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating and fatigable proximal muscle weakness. Treatment options include pyridostigmine, azathioprine, and corticosteroids. Hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the management of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, chest pain, and blue discoloration of lips. The patient reports that symptoms started a few hours after she took double the dose of the drug prescribed to her by a dermatologist for intensely pruritic erythematous papules and vesicles on elbows and knees. Past medical history is significant for celiac disease managed by strictly following a gluten-free diet. Oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry is 85% on ambient air. A 100% oxygen by nasal cannula is administered but fails to improve pulse oximetry readings or the cyanosis. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of lips and fingertips. Results of urgent laboratory investigation are shown below. Which of the following medications most likely contributed to this patient’s condition?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Arterial blood gas 
 pH  7.39 
 PaO2  142 mm Hg 
 PaCO2  34 
 Oxygen saturation  99%
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from methemoglobinemia, a complication that can occur after excessive exposure to an oxidizing agent like dapsone, which this patient was prescribed for the treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis secondary to celiac disease.    

Methemoglobin is the form of hemoglobin in which the iron molecule is in the oxidized ferric (Fe3+) state rather than in the ferrous state (Fe2+). As such, the molecule itself is unable to carry oxygen or carbon dioxide. It is commonly present with cyanosis, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain, and fatigue. This patient’s symptoms are most likely due to methemoglobinemia due to dapsone hydroxylamine’s generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS).   

Like sulfonamide, dapsone is an antimetabolite that inhibits the synthesis of dihydrofolic acid by competing with para-aminobenzoic acid for the active site of dihydropteroate synthetase (but is a structurally distinct agent). It also acts as an anti-inflammatory agent by inhibiting the migration of neutrophils to areas of inflammation. It is usually indicated in the management of leprosy (often in combination with rifampicin and clofazimine), toxoplasmosis, dermatitis herpetiformis (in combination with a gluten-free diet), and for prophylaxis against pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) in immunocompromised patients and Plasmodium falciparum malaria.    

Dose-related hemolysis is the most common side effect which can lead to hemolytic anemia (especially in those with G6PD deficiency) and methemoglobinemia. Other adverse effects including toxic hepatitis, cholestatic jaundice, nausea, headache, fatigue, insomnia, psychosis, and peripheral neuropathy have also been reported.  

Option Analysis

❌ Topical permethrin:
Incorrect: Topical permethrin 5% is the treatment of choice for scabies. It is intensely pruritic and affects the flexor surfaces of the wrist, lateral surfaces of the fingers, and the finger webs with small, crusted, red papules and linear burrows. Moreover, permethrin is not associated with the development of methemoglobinemia.  
❌ Oral sulfasalazine:
Incorrect: Although sulfasalazine can be used for the treatment of dermatitis herpetiformis in patients who are intolerant to dapsone, it is not associated with the development of methemoglobinemia.  
❌ Topical corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Although topical corticosteroids are used for the treatment of pruritis in dermatitis herpetiformis,  it is not associated with the development of methemoglobinemia.  
✅ Oral dapsone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Oral terbinafine:
Incorrect: Oral terbinafine is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of tinea corporis, which presents with a scaly erythematous rash with central clearing. This patient's skin condition is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath for the past month. The patient states that she is unable to perform simple activities without getting short of breath. Today, the patient was unable to climb the stairs and decided to come to the emergency department. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by end-stage renal disease managed with dialysis. Current medications include insulin, metformin, lisinopril and atorvastatin. The patient is non-adherent to her medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 134/83 mmHg. The EKG and chest x-ray are within normal limits. Laboratory results are shown below. There are no signs of active bleeding. The patient is given a unit of packed red blood cells with an appropriate response in her repeat hemoglobin. The physician is considering starting the patient on a medication commonly used to improve hemoglobin levels. Which of the following is a side-effect of this long-term therapy?  

Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  6.8 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  21% 
 Leukocyte count  5,000/mm3 
 Platelet count    200,000/mm3 
 Mean corpuscular volume  81 μm3 
 Serum  
 Creatinine   2.5 g/dL 
 BUN  29 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with end-stage renal disease and severe anemia which should be managed with erythropoietin.  A common side-effect of erythropoietin is hypertension.  

Kidneys have a native function of producing erythropoietin (EPO) to stimulate the bone marrow to produce red blood cells. In patients with chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease, there is insufficient production of EPO, resulting in anemia.  The medication epoetin is a recombinant erythropoietin (EPO), which stimulates the production of new red blood cells. Epoetin is an incredibly powerful drug for the treatment of anemia especially when the anemia is due to chronic renal failure, where the damaged kidneys cannot produce enough EPO. It is also effective in correcting anemias caused by other medications such as zidovudine, as well as anemia caused by certain cancers like leukemia, and anemia in critically ill patients known as anemia of chronic disease.   

It is important to note that several weeks of therapy are required before erythrocyte counts rise, so it is not an alternative to transfusing blood. In general, epoetin is a well tolerated medication, but it could cause hypertension and increase clot formation since there are more red blood cells in the blood.  



Option Analysis

❌ Capillary leak syndrome:
Incorrect: Capillary leak syndrome, where fluids leak from the capillaries into the surrounding tissue causing severe edema, can be caused by therapy with sargramostim, a synthetic version of granulocyte-monocyte-colony stimulating factor (GM-CSF). It is often used to boost myeloid precursor production and maturation. This patient is most likely started on erythropoietin.  
❌ Bone pain:
Incorrect: Bone pain is a rare side effect of filgrastim, which results from high neutrophil production in the bone marrow. Filgrastim is a recombinant granulocyte-colony stimulating factor and is used to correct neutropenia. It is not effective in treating anemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.  
✅ Hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cushing syndrome:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome is an adverse effect associated with the use of glucocorticoid therapy which is often used in the management of many autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, adrenal insufficiency and asthma. It is not effective in anemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.  
❌ Gingival hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a common side effect of cyclosporine, a calcineurin inhibitor, used in the management of psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis.  It is not effective in anemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of a two month history of weight loss and a right-sided neck mass. The patient reports a 6-lb (2.72 kg) weight loss over this same time period. He states the mass became somewhat painful on Saturday night when he was out drinking with his friends. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates right-sided, non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Hodgkin lymphoma is suspected. Which of the following biopsy results indicates a more favorable prognosis?

choices.text: Several Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by abundant lymphocytes and few eosinophils and neutrophils
Broad bands of fibrosis separating cellular nodules containing Reed-Sternberg cells
Numerous Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by fibrosis and few lymphocytes
Reed-Sternberg cells with background infiltrate of eosinophils and neutrophils

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features that are characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL), including  painless cervical lymphadenopathy, B symptoms (fever, weight loss), as well as alcohol-induced pain lymphadenitis. HL encompasses a group of B-cell neoplasms that are characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells. Five subtypes of Hodgkin lymphoma are currently recognized:  
 
  •  Nodular sclerosis is the most predominant subtype and is characterized by cellular nodules surrounded by fibrous bands of collagen.  
  •  Lymphocyte-rich and lymphocyte predominant are not common variants of HL, but they have the most favorable prognosis. As the names suggest, these variants demonstrate the RS cells surrounded by abundant lymphocytes, with few eosinophils and neutrophils. 
  •  Mixed cellularity and lymphocyte-depletion are rare variants of HL and more commonly found in immunocompromised patients. Biopsy of this variant demonstrates mixed cellularity, and classically shows the RS cells with a background infiltrate consisting of eosinophils, neutrophils, macrophages, and plasma cells. The mixed cellularity variant has a variable prognosis, while the lymphocyte-depletion variant has a poor prognosis. 


Option Analysis

✅ Several Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by abundant lymphocytes and few eosinophils and neutrophils   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Broad bands of fibrosis separating cellular nodules containing Reed-Sternberg cells   :
Incorrect: With the nodular sclerosing variant of Hodgkin lymphoma, cellular nodules are surrounded by collagen bands containing variable numbers of Reed-Sternberg cells, within a mixed inflammatory background. While this variant is the most common (>60%), a different variant is associated with a more favorable prognosis.   
❌ Numerous Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by fibrosis and few lymphocytes   :
Incorrect: This biopsy finding describes the lymphocyte-depleted variant of Hodgkin lymphoma. This variant is most commonly found in immunocompromised individuals and carries a poor prognosis.   
❌ Reed-Sternberg cells with background infiltrate of eosinophils and neutrophils   :
Incorrect: This biopsy finding describes the mixed cellularity variant of Hodgkin lymphoma. This variant is most commonly found in immunocompromised individuals and has a variable prognosis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a low-grade fever and weight loss over the past few weeks. He has not had a cough, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows non-tender lymphadenopathy of two adjacent cervical lymph nodes. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A biopsy of an affected lymph node is performed, which shows the following (see image below):  


Reproduced from: Flickr  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s age, constitutional symptoms, presence of non-tender, contiguous lymphadenopathy (meaning adjacent lymph nodes), and Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells on lymph node biopsy all suggest Hodgkin lymphoma.  

RS cells are bilobed tumor giant cells that are CD15+ and CD30+ of B-cell origin, and their presence is the hallmark finding in Hodgkin lymphoma. Hodgkin lymphoma follows a bimodal distribution. Thus younger adults and teens, as well as older adults, are affected. As opposed to non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which has non-contiguous lymphadenopathy, Hodgkin lymphoma usually has contiguous lymph node involvement. The non-tender quality of the enlarged lymph nodes suggests the lymphadenopathy is caused by a neoplasm, rather than an acute infection.

Tip: Non-Hodgkin =  Non-contiguous, while Hodgkin = contiguous  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL):
Incorrect: Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL, previously called AML-M3) is a subtype of AML. AML composes a group of hematopoietic neoplasms involving precursor cells of the myeloid lineage with a median onset of 65 years. On smear, APL cells show Auer rods cytoplasmic inclusions. Since lymph node biopsy showed Reed-Sternberg cells in this case, and the physical exam revealed lymphadenopathy, lymphoma is more likely than leukemia. Leukemia usually presents with symptoms of bone failure such as anemia and bleeding.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Smear from a patient with APL showing abnormal promyelocyte with Auer rods  
❌ Burkitt lymphoma  :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma that usually presents in adolescents or young adults. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas typically show the involvement of multiple peripheral nodes in a non-contiguous spread. On peripheral blood smear, Burkitt lymphoma shows a sheet of mature B-cells with numerous tingible-body macrophages interspersed, giving a “starry sky” appearance.  


Reproduced from: Flickr  
Burkitt lymphoma “Starry sky”  
❌ Chronic myelogenous leukemia  :
Incorrect: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm causing dysregulated production and proliferation of granulocytes. Although the patient is in the peak age range for CML (45-85 years), the lymph node biopsy showed Reed-Sternberg cells, which is diagnostic for Hodgkin lymphoma rather than leukemia.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia commons  
Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) smear showing leukocytosis with granulocyte left shift  
❌ Hairy cell leukemia  :
Incorrect: Hairy cell leukemia typically occurs in adult males and is histologically characterized by the presence of mature B-cells with abnormal, hair-like projections. The most common symptoms include pancytopenia, due to bone marrow involvement, and massive splenomegaly. Reed-Sternberg cells are not seen in this condition.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Smear showing abnormal B-cells with hair-like projections  
✅ Hodgkin lymphoma  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of weight loss and nightly fevers for the past four months. The patient has noticed lumps on his neck and under his arms that fluctuate in size. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals fixed, non-tender cervical masses and enlarged axillary lymph nodes. A biopsy of an enlarged lymph node is performed, with subsequent staining for BCL-2, as demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Further testing is most likely to reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Overactivation of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of painless waxing-and-waning lymph node enlargement, plus biopsy immunophenotyping revealing a high expression of BCL-2. Together, these findings are diagnostic for follicular lymphoma (FL). The majority of FL cases result in a genetic rearrangement that results in an inappropriate overexpression of the BCL2 protein, an inhibitor of apoptosis, causing proliferation of a single B-cell.  

Measurement of immunoglobulin light chain (i.e., kappa or lambda) expression by flow cytometry is an additional test that aids in the diagnosis and monitoring of B-cell lymphomas. Normal, reactive B-cell lymphocyte populations (such as during an active infection) exhibit expression of both kappa and lambda light chains at an expected ratio.

Neoplastic cells, in contrast, exhibit monotypia (overexpression of either kappa or lambda) because malignant cells arise from a genetic transformation and overproliferation of a single cell. Therefore, B-cell lymphomas originating from a proliferating single cell line often exhibit an expansion of either kappa or lambda light chain-expressing cells. This clonal expansion is termed monoclonal (or monotypic) light chain restriction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated kappa:lambda ratio   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Polytypic light chain expression   :
Incorrect: Normal and reactive B-cell lymphocyte populations exhibit proportionate expression of both kappa and lambda light chains. This proportionate expression of light chains results in polytypic (as opposed to monotypic seen in lymphomas) light chain expression.   
❌ Overactivation of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2   :
Incorrect: Activating mutations of the epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), a receptor tyrosine kinase, is observed in some breast cancers. The BCL-2 positive staining of this patient’s lymph node, however, is instead indicative of follicular lymphoma.   
❌ Preserved nodal architecture   :
Incorrect: Reactive follicular hyperplasia (i.e., in the setting of an active infection) results in preserved nodal architecture, whereas follicular lymphoma results in diffuse disruption of nodal architecture.   
❌ Abundance of debris-laden macrophages   :
Incorrect: Debris-laden macrophages (i.e. “tingible-body” macrophages) are observed in reactive follicular hyperplasia during an active infection. Macrophages assist in the clearance of debris from apoptotic B-cells. Follicular lymphoma, however, results in cells that can evade apoptosis, causing a relative absence of macrophages.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to her physician endorsing recurrent, painless lumps throughout her body. The patient noticed the lumps on her neck and groin several months ago, and they often cycle between enlarging and reducing. The patient does not have any fevers, night sweats, or weight loss. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several small non-tender and immobile right-sided cervical masses, as well as enlarged axillary and inguinal lymph nodes. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of painless, waxing-and-waning lymphadenopathy, which is clinically characteristic of follicular lymphoma (FL). FL is a variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The majority of cases have a characteristic (14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14. This rearrangement results in inappropriate overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis.

Patients typically present with painless peripheral adenopathy in the cervical, axillary and inguinal regions. The adenopathy commonly waxes and wanes but never completely disappears. A small portion of patients (20%) present with B symptoms (i.e., fevers, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss).

Diagnosis relies on excisional tissue biopsy of a lymph node. Follicular lymphoma is histologically characterized by clusters of packed follicles composed primarily of centrocytes (small cleaved cells) and few centroblasts (large non-cleaved cells). Staining for BCL-2 can be helpful, as this protein is overexpressed in these cells.  



Option Analysis

✅ Inhibition of programmed cell death   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Constitutive activation of transcription   :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with translocations involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that result in overexpression of the MYC transcription factor. This patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.   
❌ Defective DNA repair   :
Incorrect: Defective DNA repair can be seen in cancers due to underlying mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene. This patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.   
❌ Integration of viral genetic material   :
Incorrect: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) has been linked to the growth of various lymphomas, including Burkitt lymphoma. EBV infects B-cells and integrates its genome into the host chromosome, resulting in the production of oncogenes. However, this patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.   
❌ Constitutive tyrosine kinase activation   :
Incorrect: In chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), a part of the ABL gene on chromosome 9 (which encodes a tyrosine kinase) is translocated to chromosome 22, where it fuses with the BCR gene. This fusion gene encodes a BCR-ABL hybrid protein that results in constitutive tyrosine kinase activity. However, this patient presents with features of follicular lymphoma, which has a different pathologic mechanism.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male comes to his provider’s office for evaluation of fatigue, weakness, and 8 kg (17.6 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 2 months. Moreover, the patient reports feeling bloated after eating small quantities of food during this same time period. His past medical history is notable for hypertension, and the patient is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide. Physical exam reveals oral mucosal pallor. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Abdominal exam reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  28.5% 
 Leukocytes  2,700/mm3 
 Platelets  100,000/mm3 

Biopsy of the bone marrow biopsy shows increased fibrosis and reduced cell count. Polymerase chain reaction testing reveals a mutation in a gene encoding for a non-receptor tyrosine kinase. Which of the following diseases is also caused by an identical mutation?
questions.solution:
This patient has primary myelofibrosis, which is one of the myeloproliferative disorders. These are a group of blood disorders characterized by the excess proliferation of cells of myeloid lineage. The four high-yield myeloproliferative disorders are: polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, primary myelofibrosis, and chronic myeloid leukemia. The first three conditions are most often caused by a Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2) gene mutation. CML is caused by a t[9;22] chromosomal translocation.  

Primary myelofibrosis is characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of megakaryocytes and scar tissue deposition. Over time, the hematopoietic stem cells residing in the bone marrow are crowded out by scar tissue. This results in pancytopenia and a “dry tap” on bone marrow biopsy. This pancytopenia results in reduced production of red blood cells (anemia), platelets (increased bleeding) and white blood cells (increased infections). Some of the stem cells migrate to other organs (e.g., liver, spleen) and proliferate there. This is termed extramedullary hematopoiesis and may cause hepatosplenomegaly. The enlarged spleen and liver can compress the stomach, ultimately resulting in decreased appetite/weight loss.    

Option Analysis

❌ Fanconi anemia:
Incorrect: Fanconi anemia is caused by defects in homologous DNA recombination. Patients with this congenital condition present at a young age with pancytopenia, short stature, microcephaly, and cafe-au-lait spots. In contrast, defects in homologous DNA recombination play no role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition (primary myelofibrosis).
❌ Chronic myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is caused by a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. This results in fusion of the BCR and ABL gene, producing a tyrosine kinase with increased activity. However, the JAK2 gene mutation responsible for this patient’s condition plays no role in the pathogenesis of CML.
❌ Follicular lymphoma:
Incorrect: Follicular lymphoma is caused by a mutation in the gene encoding the Bcl-2 protein. Normally Bcl-2 keeps the mitochondrial membrane intact and prevents apoptosis. The mutation results in overexpression of Bcl-2, which prevents apoptosis and causes uncontrolled cellular proliferation. In contrast, this patient has primary myelofibrosis, which is most often secondary to a mutation in the JAK2 gene.
✅ Polycythemia vera :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is caused by a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. This disrupts the retinoic acid receptor (RAR), which is needed for myeloblast maturation. As a result, there is proliferation of myeloblasts, the unipotent stem cells that can differentiate into neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, and monocytes. However, the JAK2 gene mutation responsible for this patient’s condition plays no role in AML.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of fatigue and weight loss over the past two months. He reports early satiety and a sensation of abdominal fullness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several nontender, rubbery masses in the left axilla and right groin. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. A mass in the axilla is resected, and genetic analysis reveals a t(11;14) translocation. The translocated gene in these cells produces a protein that is directly responsible for which of the following functions?
questions.solution:
Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is a rare, aggressive subtype of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that typically occurs in men older than 50 years of age. Almost all tumors have an (11;14) translocation that fuses the BCL1 gene, normally found on chromosome 11, to the IgH locus, normally found on chromosome 14. This translocation results in overexpression of cyclin D1. This protein is responsible for transition to S phase via phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma gene product, which subsequently releases transcription factors that initiate DNA replication.

Most patients present with fatigue and lymphadenopathy, often with extensive involvement of additional organs, such as the spleen, liver, bone marrow and the gastrointestinal tract; splenomegaly in particular is often present.

Diagnosis relies on tissue biopsy (either of the enlarged lymph node or extranodal sites), which demonstrates monomorphic proliferation of B-cells and overexpression of cyclin D1. MCL is aggressive and often incurable–the median survival is 4-6 years after diagnosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Promotion from G1 to S-phase   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Inhibition of apoptosis   :
Incorrect: BCL-2 is an antiapoptotic molecule that is expressed by the BCL2 gene found on chromosome 18; it is often overexpressed in follicular lymphoma, due to a t(14;18) translocation. Instead, this patient has a t(11;14) translocation, which is involved in the promotion from G to S-phase in the cell cycle and pathogenic for mantle cell lymphoma.   
❌ Tyrosine kinase activity   :
Incorrect: Various chromosomal aberrations result in upregulated tyrosine kinase activity, such as HER2 overexpression found in many breast cancers. Instead, this patient has a t(11;14) translocation, which is involved in the promotion from G to S-phase in the cell cycle and pathogenic for mantle cell lymphoma.   
❌ Repair of damaged DNA   :
Incorrect: Defective DNA repair is often secondary to mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene. Instead, this patient has a t(11;14) translocation, which is involved in the promotion from G to S-phase in the cell cycle and pathogenic for mantle cell lymphoma.   
❌ Activation of transcription   :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with translocations involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that result in overexpression of the MYC transcription factor. This patient is presenting with mantle cell lymphoma, which has a different pathogenesis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office because of a dragging sensation in the abdomen for the past 2 months. He also reports easy fatigability in this same time period. Past medical history is significant for an upper respiratory tract infection treated with antibiotics 6 months ago. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 27 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows splenomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   600,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   60,100/mm3 
 Neutrophils  35% 
 Myelocytes  32% 
 Metamyelocytes  10% 
 Band forms  1% 
 Blast cells  1% 
 Basophils  6% 
 Eosinophils  6% 
 Lymphocytes  9% 
Peripheral blood smear is shown below:

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with dragging sensation in abdomen (due to splenomegaly), in combination with the laboratory findings of anemia, thrombocytosis and leukocytosis (particularly basophilia), is indicative of a myeloproliferative disorder. Of the options listed, chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is the most likely diagnosis.  

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of mature granulocytes. It accounts for 15-20% of leukemia in adults, with a slight male predominance. It arises from t(9;22) (Philadelphia chromosome) which encodes the bcr-abl fusion protein with increased tyrosine kinase activity causing growth-factor-independent proliferation of granulocytes.  


 CML can manifest in 3 different phases: 
  •  Chronic phase: Usually at the time of diagnosis, when patients present with fatigue, weight loss, abdominal fullness (splenomegaly). 
  •  Accelerated phase: When granulocyte differentiation and proliferation is accelerated, clinically manifesting as enlarging spleen. 
  •  Blast crisis: Transformation into acute myeloid leukemia or acute lymphoblastic leukemia. 
Laboratory evaluation is typical for leukocytosis (particularly basophilia), with a differential showing all cells of neutrophilic series (as in this patient). Additionally, the presence of a greater percentage of myelocytes than the more mature metamyelocytes is another classic finding in CML. The neutrophils are functionally abnormal with a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score (as compared to leukemoid reaction). Diagnosis is established by identification of Philadelphia chromosome on genetic analysis. Treatment option is imatinib, which is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hairy cell leukemia:
Incorrect: Although patients with hairy cell leukemia usually presents with symptomatic splenomegaly and pancytopenia, peripheral blood smear shows a mononuclear cell with indistinct cytoplasmic outline, giving it a hairy appearance.
❌ Acute myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute myeloid leukemia can also present with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia (eg, fatigue, dyspnea); however, peripheral blood smear shows myeloblasts with Auer rods and azurophilic granules in contrast to the mature neutrophils seen in this patient.
✅ Chronic myeloid leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acute lymphoblastic leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia can present with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia and splenomegaly; however, these findings are usually accompanied by lymphadenopathy, bone pain or mediastinal mass. Peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts (as opposed to mature cells in this patient’s smear).
❌ Chronic lymphocytic leukemia:
Incorrect: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a lymphoid neoplasm that can present with painless lymphadenopathy and “B symptoms” (weight loss, fevers, night sweats). Peripheral blood smear typically shows smudge cells, in contrast to the mature granulocytes seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man comes to his physician for assessment of a pruritic rash for the past two months. The patient states he has tried calamine lotion and several emollients with minimal relief. He has not used any body washes or creams. The patient has a remote history of intravenous drug use but has not used in the past year. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals a scaly rash over the chest, back, and legs. A photograph of the rash is shown. A biopsy of one of these lesions exhibits clusters of abundant lymphocytic cells with cerebriform nuclei within the epidermis and dermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduce from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mycosis fungoides (MF) is an extranodal cutaneous form of non-Hodgkin T-cell lymphoma. MF usually manifests as a nonspecific erythrodermic rash that progresses to a plaque phase and then to a tumor phase.

Histologically, neoplastic T-cells, most characteristically with a cerebriform appearance produced by marked infolding of the nuclear membranes, infiltrate the epidermis. A classic sign is Pautrier microabscesses within the epidermis. These are filled with neoplastic lymphocytes instead of normal neutrophils and macrophages.

Sézary syndrome is a clinical variant of MF that is characterized by a generalized exfoliative erythroderma, as well as tumor cells found in the bloodstream.  



Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  

Option Analysis

✅ Mycosis fungoides   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Bacillary angiomatosis   :
Incorrect: Bacillary angiomatosis occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially AIDS patients, and is characterized by vascular proliferation resulting in red or flesh-colored cutaneous lesions. Biopsy reveals vascular proliferation with abundant neutrophils. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.   
❌ Kaposi sarcoma   :
Incorrect: Kaposi sarcoma occurs in immunocompromised patients, especially patients with AIDS, and is induced by infection with HHV-8. Patients present with multiple cutaneous tumors. However, biopsy demonstrates spindle-shaped cells with leukocyte infiltration. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.   
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis presents with silvery-white scaling plaques, unlike this patient’s cutaneous lesions. Additionally, biopsy would show Munro microabscesses, which refers to an accumulation of neutrophils within the epidermis. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.   
❌ Contact dermatitis   :
Incorrect: Contact dermatitis typically occurs following exposure to an irritant (e.g., poison ivy, nickel, soaps), which this patient lacks. This patient’s biopsy results are indicative of another condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of fever and weight loss for the past two months. The patient states he has noted various non-tender lumps on his body, in particular one in his neck that has grown rapidly over the past few weeks. The patient has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals several nontender, enlarged supraclavicular and axillary lymph nodes. A CT chest-abdomen-pelvis reveals enlarged mesenteric and mediastinal lymph nodes. Analysis of a biopsied axillary lymph node demonstrates lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20. Further genetic analysis reveals a translocation involving the BCL6 gene on chromosome 3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), is the most common type of lymphoma in adults, accounting for nearly 35% of adult NHLs. The pathogenesis of DLBCL typically involves the BCL6 gene – either via chromosomal rearrangement of this gene, or an activating mutation in the promoter region of this gene – and upregulation of transcriptional regulators in germinal center B-cells. Another genetic etiology of DLBCL involves a t(14;18) translocation involving the BCL2 gene.

Patients typically present with a rapidly enlarging symptomatic mass, most commonly in the neck or abdomen. Systemic B symptoms (i.e., fever, weight loss, drenching night sweats) are often present. The diagnosis of DLBCL relies on excisional tissue biopsy, most commonly from a lymph node. Further immunophenotyping reveals tumor cells expressing pan B-cell antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a).  



Option Analysis

✅ Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Burkitt lymphoma   :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma (BL) is an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that can also present with B symptoms, painless lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. However, BL is more common in children and typically associated with EBV infection. In adults, BL occurs in association with an immunocompromised state, such as HIV infection. Therefore, it is not the most likely diagnosis in this patient’s case.   
❌ Hairy cell leukemia   :
Incorrect: Hairy cell leukemia is an indolent, low-grade variant of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Patients typically present with fatigue and splenomegaly. The indolent nature of this disease contrasts with this patient’s diffuse lymphadenopathy following a short period of symptoms.   
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma   :
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) may also present with lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (fevers, night sweats, weight loss). However, Hodgkin lymphomas lack the usual B-cell markers, such as CD19 and CD20 seen in this patient; instead, immunophenotyping in Hodgkin lymphoma demonstrates CD15/30-positive Reed-Sternberg cells. Therefore, HL is not the most likely diagnosis.  
❌ Follicular lymphoma   :
Incorrect: Follicular lymphoma is an indolent form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that presents with B symptoms and painless lymphadenopathy. However, follicular lymphoma is indolent and would not explain this patient’s diffuse lymphadenopathy after a short period of symptoms.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a sore throat for the past 2 days. The patient’s parent reports that the patient feels tired all the time and has not been interested in playing his favorite video games over the last several weeks. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema without exudates, mucosal pallor and petechiae on lower extremities. Abdominal examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear is shown below:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

The cells stain positive for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and CD10. The cells identified in this patient’s peripheral blood smear are precursors to which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This child’s presentation with fever, fatigue and sore throat (infection), together with lymphoblasts on peripheral smear and positive cell staining for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and CD10, is strongly suggestive of B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL).  

ALL is a neoplasm of pre-B or pre-T cells. It is defined as the clonal expansion of malignant lymphoblasts in the bone marrow. It is the most common cancer in children and occurs more frequently in boys. It is associated with Down syndrome. Pathogenesis involves chromosomal aberrations including mutations in NOTCH1 (T-ALL) or translocation of t(12;21) or, rarely, t(9;22) (B-ALL). B-ALL accounts for approximately 70-80% of cases and peaks at around 3 years of age. Lymphoblasts stain positive for TdT, a specialized DNA polymerase that is expressed in pre-B and pre-T cells. B-cell lymphoblasts express CD10, CD19 and CD20.  

Clinically, ALL presents with findings of anemia (fatigue, dyspnea), thrombocytopenia (easy bruising), dysfunctional leukocytes (infections), hepatosplenomegaly, and/or lymphadenopathy. It may also manifest with mass effects secondary to neoplastic infiltration of the sub-periosteum (bone pain, refusal to bear weight), the central nervous system (headache, vomiting) or, rarely, the testicles (seen in T-ALL). Bone marrow biopsy shows ≥20% lymphoblasts which have scant basophilic cytoplasm and a large nucleus. Definitive diagnosis requires immunophenotypic evidence of lymphoid lineage by flow cytometry. Prognosis depends on age, gender and translocation (t[9;22] is associated with a worse prognosis).  



Option Analysis

❌ Monocytes:
Incorrect: The precursors of monocytes (myeloblasts, monoblasts and promonocytes) give rise to the M4 and M5 subtypes of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML is uncommon in children and expresses monocyte differentiation markers (e.g. CD14, CD4, CD64). Moreover, peripheral blood smear shows immature monoblasts with nuclear atypia and fine azurophilic granules.  
✅ B lymphocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ T lymphocytes:
Incorrect: Although T and B cell precursors appear similar on peripheral blood smear and both stain positive for TdT, pre-T cell surface markers are different and include CD2-5, CD7 and CD8. Moreover, T-ALL usually presents in adolescence with an anterior mediastinal mass and/or mass effects (eg, SVC-like syndrome, dysphagia, dyspnea).  
❌ Erythrocytes:
Incorrect: A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia, pure erythroid leukemia (M6) arises from erythroid precursors and mostly occurs in elderly patients. The cells express CD117 and appear on peripheral smear as abnormal erythroblasts with nuclear pulverization (loss of normal nuclear architecture), admixed with myeloblasts.  
❌ Platelets:
Incorrect: Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (M7), arises from mutations involving primitive megakaryoblasts. It is associated with Down syndrome and does not cause splenomegaly. Megakaryocytic surface markers include CD41 and CD61.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 2 months. The patient states that she feels tired all day and has little energy to get out of bed. She also reports frequently stopping to catch her breath after climbing a flight of stairs. Past medical history is significant for breast cancer treated with chemoradiotherapy 10 years ago. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor but no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory evaluation reveals:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   8.0 g/dL 
 Platelet count   70,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count   16,100/mm3 

Peripheral blood smear is shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation (fatigue, dyspnea) in combination with laboratory evidence of anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis, and peripheral blood smear showing myeloblasts with Auer rods, is consistent with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).  

AML is defined as clonal expansion of malignant immature myeloid cells (>20%) in the bone marrow. It usually arises in older adults (average 50-60 years) and is mostly a result of acquired chromosomal abnormalities, particularly translocations. These mutations cause proliferation of immature myeloid cells in the bone marrow, which suppresses the growth and proliferation of other hematopoietic stem cells. Risk factors for the development of AML include radiation, chemotherapy (as in this patient), tobacco smoking, Down syndrome, and myeloproliferative disorders.

AML is divided into eight types (M0 through M7) based on cytogenetic abnormalities, cell lineage and surface markers. It commonly presents with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia (fatigue, dyspnea, easy bruising and infections). Laboratory analysis may show normochromic normocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and leukocytosis (due to circulating blasts). Peripheral blood smear reveals myeloblasts with nuclear atypia and fine azurophilic granules. Auer rods are pathognomonic of AML and appear as pink/red rod-like granular structures in the cytoplasm, as shown with the arrow below. Definitive diagnosis requires bone marrow aspiration and biopsy showing ≥20% blast cells.  


Retrieved from:Wikimedia Commons  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute lymphoblastic leukemia:
Incorrect: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is common in children and usually presents with bone pain. Peripheral blood smear shows blast cells with scant agranular cytoplasm and inconspicuous nucleoli. This patient’s peripheral blood smear is evident of myeloblasts.
✅ Acute myelogenous leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Hairy cell leukemia:
Incorrect: Patients with hairy cell leukemia usually presents with symptomatic splenomegaly and pancytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows a mononuclear cell with indistinct cytoplasmic outline, giving it a hairy appearance. This smear instead reveals myeloblasts and Auer rods, indicative of AML.
❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: Although infectious mononucleosis is a common cause of prolonged fever and fatigue, it is usually accompanied by pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear shows atypical lymphocytes (not myeloblasts).
❌ Recurrence of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Recurrence of breast cancer usually presents as a mass in the chest wall, regional lymphadenopathy (e.g., infraclavicular, supraclavicular, and axillary regions), or changes in the overlying skin. Though it can also present with signs of metastatic disease, bone marrow involvement with pancytopenia is rare. Moreover, myeloblasts with Auer rods are not seen.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive weakness and a dragging sensation in the abdomen for the past 3 months. The patient is a retired farmer. Past medical history is noncontributory. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor, petechiae on the lower extremities, and splenomegaly crossing the midline. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   9.3 g/dL 
 Platelets   70,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   6,000/mm3 
Peripheral blood smear is shown:


Reproduced from:Wikimedia Commons 

Which of the following genes is most likely to be mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive weakness and massive splenomegaly, along with laboratory findings of pancytopenia and hairy cells on peripheral smear, most likely has hairy cell leukemia (HCL).  

HCL is a chronic progressive B cell lymphoproliferative disorder that results in infiltration of bone marrow and reticuloendothelial system. It constitutes about 2% of all leukemias and appears to be more common in males. Median age of incidence is 55 years. In most cases, it results from an activating point mutation in BRAF (serine/threonine), leading to self-sustained activation of RAF-MEK-ERK signaling pathway, which causes the accelerated proliferation of lymphocytes in the bone marrow. It eventually causes bone marrow fibrosis, resulting in a dry tap on aspiration and leading to pancytopenia (fever, fatigue, weakness and recurrent infections). The neoplastic cells also infiltrate the red pulp of the spleen, leading to splenomegaly, which can present as a dragging sensation in the abdomen (as in this patient), as well as early satiety due to compression of the stomach.  

Peripheral blood smear shows lymphocytes with cytoplasmic projections (irregular cytoplasm outline). Additionally, the stain for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is characteristically positive in HCL. Diagnosis is established by flow cytometry specific for B-cell markers (CD20, CD22, CD25). Treatment options include various chemotherapeutic agents, and the overall prognosis is excellent. Tumors with an underlying BRAF mutation that fail conventional therapy have strong responses to BRAF inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

❌ RB1:
Incorrect: RB1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for retinoblastoma protein. Inactivating mutations in RB1 is associated with the development of retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, not hairy cell leukemia.  
✅ BRAF:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ RET:
Incorrect: Multiple neuroendocrine neoplasia 2 (MEN2) results from germ-line mutations in RET proto-oncogene. MEN2 mutations are associated with pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid hyperplasia and mucosal neuromas. Pancytopenia and peripheral cells with hairy cytoplasmic projections suggests a leukemic disorder.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: HER2 overexpression is involved in the pathogenesis of invasive breast cancers and is unlikely to be mutated in this patient presenting with classic signs and symptoms of hairy cell leukemia.
❌ VHL:
Incorrect: Loss of function mutations in VHL are seen in renal cell carcinoma (presenting with abdominal mass and hematuria) or von Hippel-Landau syndrome (associated with hemangioblastomas, pheochromocytomas, and bilateral renal cell carcinomas). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of a leukemic disorder.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of fatigue and abdominal pain for the past several months. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease, but he has been inconsistent with treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Urea breath test is positive. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a mass in the gastric antrum. Biopsy of the mass demonstrates diffuse infiltrates of small lymphoid CD20-positive cells. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen reveals enlarged regional lymph nodes. This patient’s condition is most highly associated with which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a positive urea breath test and history of peptic ulcer disease and likely has H. pylori-induced gastritis. Chronic inflammation can result in clonal expansion of B-cells and development of marginal zone lymphoma (MZL). Biopsy often demonstrates an infiltrate of small B-cells that express the B-cell markers CD19, CD20, and CD22.

MZL is an indolent variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It tends to develop within tissues subjected to chronic mucosal inflammation due to primary autoimmune disorders (such as the salivary gland in Sjögren syndrome or the thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditis) or due to infection (such as the stomach in H. pylori gastritis). In the case of gastric MZL, treatment with antibiotic therapy often leads to regression of the disease.  



Option Analysis

✅ Sjögren syndrome   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Ulcerative colitis   :
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis is associated with a substantially increased risk of developing colon cancer, not marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).   
❌ Hemochromatosis   :
Incorrect: Hemochromatosis is associated with an elevated risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma, not marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).   
❌ Graves disease   :
Incorrect: Graves disease has not been shown to increase the risk of thyroid-related cancers. In contrast, patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis do have an increased risk of developing marginal zone lymphoma (MZL).   
❌ Systemic sclerosis   :
Incorrect: Systemic sclerosis (SS), an autoimmune disease involving the skin and viscera, may result in an elevated risk of various cancers, although the link has not been fully established. However, marginal zone lymphoma (MZL) has not been shown to be associated with SS.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal results of a routine blood count. The patient does not have any symptoms of fatigue, malaise, fever, or shortness of breath. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged, firm, mobile cervical lymph nodes on both sides. Fecal occult blood is negative. Laboratory results are shown.  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   90,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   20,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils  20% 
 Lymphocytes  75% 
 Eosinophils  2% 
 Basophils  1% 
 Monocytes  1% 
After appropriate workup, flow cytometry is indicated which shows the following results.
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with lymphadenopathy, lymphocytosis, and flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation (CD20 and CD5) is strongly suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL).  

CLL/SLL arises from oncogenic mutations that cause inhibition of apoptosis and monoclonal expansion of B cells, resulting in their accumulation in the peripheral blood and bone marrow. It is the most common leukemia in adults in the Western world, and it is almost always seen in the elderly (median age of diagnosis is 70). It is usually asymptomatic (as in this patient) but can present with “B symptoms” (fever, weight loss, night sweats and fatigue). Lymphadenopathy (cervical, supraclavicular and/or axillary), hepatomegaly and splenomegaly are common findings on examination. Lymph nodes appear as round, firm, mobile and nontender masses on palpation.  

 Proliferation centers in lymph nodes, which are loose aggregates of large lymphocytes, are pathognomonic of CLL/SLL. On laboratory evaluation, lymphocytosis (>5000/mL) is present in association with anemia, neutropenia and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and a few cells disrupted in the process of making smear, called smudge (smear) cells (mnemonic: CLL = Crushed Little Lymphocytes). Immunophenotype analysis by using flow cytometry is key to make a definitive diagnosis, which shows clonal expansion of B-cells expressing CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23.  

A small fraction of patients with CLL/SLL can develop transformation to aggressive tumors resembling diffuse large B cell lymphoma (Richter transformation). This should be suspected in patients with CLL/SLL who develop rapidly progressive lymphadenopathy or extranodal sites of disease, systemic symptoms, or elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase, indicative of a rapidly proliferating tumor.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Hairy cell leukemia:
Incorrect: Although hairy cell leukemia is also a mature B cell neoplasm, it usually presents with pancytopenia and massive splenomegaly. Additionally, lymphadenopathy is atypical and should prompt investigation for a different underlying condition.
✅ Chronic lymphocytic leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Chronic myeloid leukemia:
Incorrect: Chronic myeloid leukemia is a myeloproliferative (not lymphoproliferative) neoplasm characterized by uncontrolled production of mature granulocytes. Lymphocyte count is usually not affected, and blood count usually reveals elevated myelocytes and basophils. Moreover, CD20 cells on flow cytometry are indicative of a B-cell neoplasm.
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with asymptomatic lymphadenopathy or a mediastinal mass and constitutional symptoms (fever, night sweats and weight loss). It does not usually cause anemia or lymphocytosis.
❌ Aplastic anemia:
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure causing pancytopenia, not lymphocytosis. A clonal B cell proliferation, as demonstrated by this patient's flow cytometry, is not typical.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of worsening abdominal pain over the past three months. He has not had a bowel movement in three days. The patient’s parent reports an 11-lb (5 kg) weight loss and fevers most nights over this same time period. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates abdominal distension and diffuse tenderness to palpation with a positive fluid wave test. A CT scan of the abdomen shows para-aortic and mesenteric lymph node enlargement and a 7cm x 7cm enhancing mesenteric mass. A biopsy of one of the aforementioned lymph nodes is performed, and the histologic findings are demonstrated below.  


Reproduced from: Flickr  
Which of the following chromosomal translocations is most likely present in cells obtained from the lymph node?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with signs of a bowel obstruction secondary to an enlarging abdominal mass and biopsy results confirming the diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma (BL). BL is highly associated with translocations involving the MYC gene on chromosome 8 (most commonly to chromosome 14), resulting in overexpression of the MYC transcription factor. MYC is a major regulator of aerobic glycolysis, which is predominantly seen in tumors demonstrating rapid cell growth.

Two distinct clinical forms of BL are seen in children: endemic and sporadic (non-endemic). The endemic variant is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections and typically present as a rapidly growing mandibular mass. Currently, this variant is seen most commonly in regions of Africa where EBV is endemic. In contrast, the sporadic variant typically presents with abdominal symptoms and often involves the ileocecal junction, resulting in bowel obstructions and ascites.

Biopsy of the mass or adjacent lymph nodes is necessary for diagnosis. A tissue sample of BL classically demonstrates a "starry sky” appearance. The “sky” is composed of a large number of medium-sized neoplastic B-cells with minimal cytoplasm. The “stars” are tingible-body macrophages that contain dead neoplastic cells. Upon fixation, the peripheral cytoplasmic space surrounding the phagocytosed debris is washed away, creating round white spaces.  




Option Analysis

✅ t(8;14)   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ t(9;22)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(9;22), also known as the Philadelphia translocation, is associated with the majority of chronic myeloid leukemia cases (CML). CML occurs in older patients (50-60 years old). A peripheral blood analysis reveals a significant leukocytosis with the presence of basophilia and eosinophilia. This young child’s presentation and biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ t(12;21)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(12;21) is the most common chromosomal rearrangement in childhood B-cell acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). The peak incidence of ALL is in children aged 2-5, who usually present with episodes of bleeding (e.g., petechiae, hematoma). This patient’s biopsy findings suggest a different condition.   
❌ t(14;18)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(14;18) is associated with follicular lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which are variants of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma presents as a slowly progressive, painless lymphadenopathy, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma typically presents in adults. This young child’s presentation and biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ t(11;14)   :
Incorrect: Translocation t(11;14) is associated with mantle cell lymphoma, which is more common in older men. This young child’s presentation and biopsy results suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic because of progressive fatigue, fevers, and night sweats for the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for 3 episodes of sinusitis in the last 6 months, which all resolved with the use of oral antibiotics. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and purpuric rashes on lower extremities. There is no lymphadenopathy.  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
Complete blood count 
Hemoglobin   8.5 g/dL 
 Platelet count   70,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count   6,000/mm3 
After appropriate workup, bone marrow biopsy reveals the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with symptomatic pancytopenia (fatigue, fever, night sweats, tachycardia) and bone marrow biopsy showing myeloblasts is consistent with leukemia. Leukemia is a myeloid or lymphoid malignancy resulting in widespread involvement of bone marrow. The common types of leukemia include:  

  1.  Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) 
  2.  Chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) 
  3.  Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) 
  4.  Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) 


Several genetic and environmental factors are associated with its development, including trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), chromosomal translocations or deletions, smoking, ionizing radiation, and chemotherapy. Clinical findings include fatigue or dyspnea (secondary to the anemia), petechiae or purpura (thrombocytopenia), and frequent infections (abnormal leukocyte function). Physical examination often reveals enlargement of reticuloendothelial system (lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly) and skin changes (leukemia cutis). Definitive diagnosis usually requires bone marrow biopsy or flow cytometry analysis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: Infectious mononucleosis usually presents with a triad of fever, pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear reveals atypical lymphocytosis. However, pancytopenia would not be observed, and this patient does not have lymphadenopathy or pharyngitis.
✅ Leukemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Lymphoma:
Incorrect: Lymphoma is a malignancy of lymphoid tissue including lymph node, thymus, spleen and bone marrow. It usually presents with a painless lymph node enlargement and “B symptoms” (fever, night sweats, unexplained weight loss). Bone marrow biopsy in any type of lymphoma would not show Auer rods or myeloblasts.   
❌ Aplastic anemia:
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia results from bone marrow failure usually due to immune-mediated injury to hematopoietic stem cells triggered by a drug, virus or chemicals. Although it may also present with signs and symptoms of pancytopenia, bone marrow biopsy would instead show a hypocellular marrow with fat cells and marrow stroma.
❌ Immune thrombocytopenic purpura:
Incorrect: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is an acquired cause of immune-mediated thrombocytopenia that results from autoantibodies against platelet antigens. It is asymptomatic in most patients but may present with petechiae, purpura or hemorrhagic bleeding in severe cases. It results in an isolated thrombocytopenia, as opposed to the pancytopenia seen in this patient.

questions.text:
40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of recurrent epistaxis and ongoing gingival bleeding. She has no history of trauma. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for hemophilia A in her brother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows mucosal pallor and petechiae on the lower extremities. There is ongoing oozing of blood from the gingiva. Laboratory studies are shown:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin   8.6 g/dL 
 Platelets   60,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   3,500/mm3 
 Coagulation profile 
 Prothrombin time (PT)  25 sec 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  50 sec 
 Bleeding time (BT)   11 minutes 
 Plasma fibrinogen  150 mg/dL   (N = 200-400 mg/dL) 
 D-dimer   1200 ng/dL   (N = <500 ng/mL) 

After stabilization and appropriate workup, bone marrow biopsy is performed and is shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Chromosomal analysis of the abnormal cells will most likely show which of the following abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of recurrent epistaxis, ongoing gingival bleeding and abnormal coagulation profile (increased PT, aPTT, BT and decreased fibrinogen) suggest disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). In association with pancytopenia and typical bone marrow biopsy findings of myeloblasts with Auer rods, acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is the most likely diagnosis.

Acute myeloid leukemia is a myeloid stem cell malignancy that results in failure of differentiation of myeloid precursors into mature granulocytes, on the basis of which it is divided into 8 types (M0 through M7). APML, the M3 subtype, is due to t(15;17) translocation, which links the retinoic acid receptor α (RARA) gene on chromosome 15 to promyelocytic leukemia (PML) gene on chromosome 17, creating a fusion gene PML-RARA. It encodes an abnormal retinoic acid receptor which interrupts the differentiation of promyelocytes, leading to the development of APML.    

Clinically, it can present with anemia (fatigue, dyspnea), thrombocytopenia (easy bruising, epistaxis) and abnormal leukocyte function (infections). DIC is a potential complication of APML. Bone marrow biopsy shows neoplastic promyelocytes with azurophilic granules, bilobed nuclei and pink cytoplasmic rod-like structures called Auer rods (arrows). Definitive diagnosis is established by identifying PML-RARA fusion gene on fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis. APML is treated with all-trans retinoic acid.  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Option Analysis

❌ 13q deletion:
Incorrect: Deletion of 13q is usually seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a B-cell neoplasm, but this patient’s bone marrow biopsy instead shows abnormal myeloid cells.  
❌ t(8;14):
Incorrect: Translocation of chromosome 8 on 14 is seen in Burkitt lymphoma. It usually presents with a mass in the facial or abdominal region. Bone marrow biopsy shows uniform neoplastic cells with evenly interspersed reactive tingible-body macrophages, resulting in a characteristic "starry-sky" pattern. It is not associated with DIC.  
✅ t(15;17):
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ t(9;22):
Incorrect: Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22] bcr-abl) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia. It is mostly asymptomatic or presents with nonspecific symptoms (fatigue, weight loss). Coagulation profile is normal. Bone marrow biopsy shows mature neoplastic myeloid cells rather than myeloblasts (immature myeloid cells), as seen in this patient.  
❌ t(14;18):
Incorrect:  t(14;18) is typical of follicular lymphoma (non-Hodgkin lymphoma). It usually presents with waxing and waning courses of lymphadenopathy. This patient’s presentation with immature myeloblast proliferation in bone marrow and DIC is consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the office due to 2 days of sore throat, purulent nasal discharge and facial pain. Past medical history is significant for several sinus infections over the past 6 months, all of which resolved with oral antibiotics. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.4°F), pulse is 80/minute, respirations are 19/minute, and blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema and maxillary sinus tenderness. There is no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results are as follows:    
Laboratory value  Result
Complete blood count 
Hemoglobin   10 g/dL 
 Platelets   600,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes   100,100/mm3 
 Neutrophils  40% 
 Myelocytes  32% 
 Metamyelocytes  10% 
 Band forms  1% 
 Blast cells  1% 
 Lymphocytes  7% 
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis reveals a bcr-abl fusion gene. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Auer rods on peripheral blood smear
Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration
Flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation (CD20 and CD5)

questions.solution:
This patient with leukocytosis and bcr-abl fusion gene on genetic analysis most likely has chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).  

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of mature granulocytes. It is usually a result of the translocation of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 to the ABL gene on chromosome 9, leading to the formation of the oncogenic BCR-ABL fusion gene on the shortened chromosome 22 (known as Philadelphia chromosome with t[9;22]). Laboratory investigation usually shows leukocytosis (>100,000/mL) with neutrophilia.    

An elevated percentage of myelocytes as compared to mature metamyelocytes (myeloid bulge) and a low leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score helps differentiate CML from a leukemoid reaction; leukemoid reactions are typically seen in response to infections or drugs (e.g. steroids). A high LAP score is associated with an increased number of mature white blood cells (as in leukemoid reactions), whereas a low LAP score is associated with an increased number of immature white blood cells (as in CML).  
An absolute basophilia is also characteristic of CML. Eosinophil and platelet count may also be elevated. Peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy show granulocyte hyperplasia with more mature forms and are important investigations to determine the phase of disease (chronic, accelerated, or blast crisis). Definitive diagnosis is established by genetic testing demonstrating the bcr-abl fusion gene.




Option Analysis

❌ Auer rods on peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: Auer rods are pathognomonic of acute myeloid leukemia. Peripheral blood or bone marrow blast cells should be ≥20% to establish the diagnosis, unlike the 1% blast cells in this patient.
❌ Elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score:
Incorrect: An elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is typically found in leukemoid reaction, which occurs in response to an infection. Leukocyte count can be as high as 50,000/microL with neutrophilia and marked left shift. The elevated myelocytes as compared to metamyelocytes and the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (bcr-abl) on FISH analysis are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
❌ Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration:
Incorrect: Dry tap on bone marrow aspiration is usually seen in hairy cell leukemia, which presents with pancytopenia and massive splenomegaly. Elevated leukocyte counts and the bcr-abl fusion gene are suggestive of a different underlying diagnosis. 
❌ Flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation (CD20 and CD5):
Incorrect: Flow cytometry showing clonal B cell proliferation is diagnostic for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. It is asymptomatic in most cases or presents with “B symptoms” (fever, weight loss, night sweats and fatigue). Lymphadenopathy is usually present. This patient’s laboratory and genetic findings are suggestive of a different diagnosis.  
✅ Absolute basophilia:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to her physician due to weight loss and fatigue for two months. The patient reports night sweats and high fevers, stating that she has been “soaking the bed sheets through” at night. The patient has no significant past medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals nontender cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following clinical features favors a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma over non-Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of localized lymphadenopathy and B symptoms (e.g., fever, night sweats, weight loss) raises concern for Hodgkin lymphoma (HL). HL encompasses a group of neoplasms histologically characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, which are bilobed tumor giant cells (“owl-eye”). HL arises from germinal center B-cells and has a bimodal distribution; the first peak occurring in patients aged 25-30, while the second peak occurs in patients aged 50-70.  

Unlike most non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs), HL arises in a single lymph node and spreads in a stepwise fashion to anatomically contiguous nodes. Extranodal involvement is uncommon in HL, whereas it is more commonly seen in NHL. Definitive diagnosis, however, still relies on the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in lymph node biopsy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Contiguous lymph node spread   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Presence of constitutional symptoms   :
Incorrect: Constitutional symptoms (fevers, night sweats, weight loss) are common to both Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   
❌ Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase   :
Incorrect: As malignant cells proliferate and outgrow their vascular supply, they release their intracellular contents–including lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Thus LDH can be elevated in both Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   
❌ Elevated serum calcium   :
Incorrect: Paraneoplastic production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D and subsequent hypercalcemia is common to both Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.   
❌ Involvement of multiple peripheral nodes   :
Incorrect: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma involves multiple peripheral nodes. Hodgkin lymphoma, in contrast, is commonly localized to a single axial group of nodes (e.g., cervical, mediastinal, paraaortic).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old female comes to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of fatigue, weakness, and 8 kg (17.6 lb) unintentional weight loss over the past two-months. In addition, the patient reports having a decreased appetite. Her medical history is notable for a viral upper respiratory tract infection that self-resolved six weeks ago. Physical exam reveals oral mucosal pallor. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Abdominal exam reveals an enlarged liver and spleen. A fecal occult blood test is negative. Complete blood count reveals a leukocyte count of 3,700/mm3 and platelet count of 98,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear is ordered and the results are as follows:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following findings would help confirm this patient’s diagnosis?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy showing fibrosis and increased megakaryocyte count
Bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity and fatty infiltration
Colonoscopy revealing a neoplasm of the large intestines
Serum protein electrophoresis showing increased immunoglobulin levels
Iron studies revealing reduced serum iron and ferritin levels

questions.solution:
This patient has primary myelofibrosis, a condition that causes uncontrolled megakaryocyte proliferation. It is often secondary to mutations in the Janus Kinase 2, MPL, or Calreticulin genes. The mutated megakaryocytes produce large quantities of platelets and cytokines, one of which is fibroblast growth factor (FGF). FGF activates fibroblasts and causes scar tissue deposition. Over time, hematopoietic stem cells are crowded out of the bone marrow by scar tissue. Some of the stem cells migrate to other organs and proliferate there, resulting in extramedullary hematopoiesis.  

Patients present with symptoms secondary to decreased RBC count (e.g., fatigue, mucosal pallor) and decreased WBC count (e.g. recurrent infections). In early stages of the disease, patients have platelet overproduction and this increases their risk of thrombotic events. In later stages, when the bone marrow is fibrosed, patients develop thrombocytopenia and are at increased bleeding risk. Extramedullary hematopoiesis can cause hepatosplenomegaly.  

Work-up includes a complete blood count, peripheral blood smear, bone marrow biopsy, and genetic testing. Peripheral blood smear will show dacrocytes (teardrop-shaped RBCs that managed to squeeze out of the bone marrow). Bone marrow biopsy will show extensive fibrosis with few cells (dry tap) and genetic testing will likely confirm the presence of a mutation (e.g. JAK2).  
 

Option Analysis

✅ Bone marrow biopsy showing fibrosis and increased megakaryocyte count  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bone marrow biopsy showing hypocellularity and fatty infiltration:
Incorrect: This finding would suggest aplastic anemia. Viral infections can cause aplastic anemia. However, aplastic anemia secondary to a viral infection typically self-resolves within a few days to weeks. Moreover, it would be atypical for aplastic anemia to cause hepatosplenomegaly or dacrocytes (tear drop cells).  
❌ Colonoscopy revealing a neoplasm of the large intestines:
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer can cause anemia due to occult blood loss. This would account for the fatigue, weakness, and red blood cell (RBC) pallor.
